Title: Load analysis on the bridge structure according to RSNI T 02-2005 and SNI 1725-2006
Source title: International Journal of Emerging Trends in Engineering Research
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Rachmat, F., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The rapid development of infrastructure in civil engineering must be compensated with the latest regulations to adapt to the current conditions, especially in the construction of bridge infrastructure, and therefore the government issued the latest loading regulation on bridge structure that is SNI 1725-2016. The bridge is important because it serves as a liaison between two separate places due to several conditions. This research is conducted to find out whether existing bridge can still meet the criteria of stress, deflection, and deformation based on load value factor, load action, and load combination on SNI 1725-2016. The earthquake load used is a response spectrum using SNI 2833: 2013 regulations[1]. This research uses finite element method using software midas civil software program. In this analysis it is found that the value of stress, deflection, and deformation on the bridge structure according to SNI 1725-2016 is greater than RSNI T 02-2005. © 2020, World Academy of Research in Science and Engineering. All rights reserved.

Title: Seismic performance of reinforced concrete structures with pushover analysis
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pierre, A.J., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: A building that looks strong enough might possibly collapse due to the earthquake load. Earthquake resistant design is generally based on an analysis of elastic structures that are given a load factor to simulate ultimate conditions. When an earthquake occurs, the collapse behavior of a building structure is inelastic. Evaluations that can estimate the inelastic condition of buildings during an earthquake are analyzed using pushover analysis. Pushover analysis is the nonlinear static load of the structural collapse behavior of an earthquake, while the performance point is the magnitude of the maximum displacement of the structure during a earthquake. The inelastic structure analysis and evaluation method used computer application SAP 2000. Evaluation results of structural performance levels according to Applied Technology Council 40 (ATC-40) on the X and Y direction structure, the maximum total drift and total inelastic drift maximum values in the X and Y directions included in the Immediate Occupancy (IO) level category (maximum drift value of a building structure 0.00047 < 0.005). © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: pushover analysis; reinforced concrete; seismic performance
Index Keywords: Earthquake engineering; Reinforced concrete; Seismic waves; Structural analysis; Earthquake-resistant design; Inelastic structure; Maximum displacement; Performance points; Push-over analysis; Seismic Performance; Structural collapse; Structural performance; Earthquakes

Authors: Santoso K.R., Hidayat I., Suangga M.
Title: Displacement and curvature ductility in mid-rise reinforced concrete buildings
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Santoso, K.R., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: When an earthquake occurs, ductility will maintain strength and stiffness in the structure so that the building structure still works even though it is on the verge of collapse. To get a description of the structural behavior starting from the structure in linear elastic, the first yielding of the structural elements until the structure collapse due to earthquake load, it can be done with non-linear static analysis namely pushover analysis. In this study, the geometry of mid-rise reinforced concrete structure consists of four storey buildings. The dimensions of the column structure 400x400 mm and beam structure 250x500 mm, where the dimensions of the beams and columns are the same from the 1st floor to the 4th floor. To find out the behavior that affects the ductility value in mid-rise reinforced concrete structures, a variation material used in this study are the spacing of stirrup, ratio of longitudinal reinforcement, ratio of compressive and tensile longitudinal reinforcement, and compressive strength of concrete. Structural geometry modeling, structural loads, and modeling of material variations used the program SAP 2000. From the output of this program, an analysis of the value of curvature ductility and displacement ductility was performed. The result of this study are the higher the value of compressive strength of concrete and the ratio of longitudinal reinforcement in beam structure will increase the value of ductility. The smaller the value of the spacing of stirrup and the ratio of longitudinal reinforcement in column structure will increase the value of ductility. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Compressive strength; Concrete buildings; Concrete construction; Ductility; Earthquakes; Floors; Prestressed beams and girders; Static analysis; Structural analysis; Compressive strength of concrete; Curvature ductility; Displacement ductility; Longitudinal reinforcement; Non-linear static analysis; Pushover; Strength and stiffness; Structural behaviors; Reinforced concrete

Authors: Suangga M., Candra H., Hidayat I., Yuliastuti
Title: Temperature effect on tension force of stay cable of cable-stayed bridge
Source title: International Journal of Engineering and Advanced Technology
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Candra, H., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Yuliastuti, Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Cable is the main element of cable-supported bridge, such as suspension bridge, cable stayed bridge and arch bridge. For the cable-stayed bridge, the cable receives the load from the bridge deck and transfer it to the pylon. As the ambient temperature change, the internal force in bridge element including stayed cable will change. This research investigate the ambient temperature effect to the tension force of stayed cable of cable-stayed bridge by comparing the result of finite element model analysis with the field measurement form electromagnetic sensor data. The finite element model of Merah Putih Cable-Stayed Bridge has been developed based on detailed engineering design data. The finite element model is validated using the natural frequency data from dynamic load test of the bridge. The ambient temperature and bridge elements temperature were measured for 24 hours. The finite element analysis were conducted based on field measurement data and the contribution of pylon and girder temperature to the cable tension forces variation was investigated. The output of finite element analysis then compared to the actual cable tension as measured by an electromagnetic sensor. It was found that the ambient temperature will affecting the magnitude of tension force at stay cable and the variation of cable tension has similar pattern of both from the finite element model and electromagnetic data. As the temperature of bridge element increases or decreases, the bridge will experience a deformation. Since the stay cable connected to the pylon at one side and to the girder at the other side, its will make the stay cable elongated or contracted which in turn will affecting the tension force at stay cable. When evaluating the bridge condition based on the tension force at stay cable, the effect of temperature variation need to be considered. © BEIESP.
Author Keywords: Cable; Cable tension; Cable-stayed bridge; Electromagnetic sensor; Finite element method; Temperature
Funding Text 1: This work is supported by the Directorate General of Strengthening for Research and Development, Ministry of Research, Technology, and Higher Education, Republic of Indonesia as a part of Penelitian Terapan Unggulan Perguruan Tinggi Research Grant to Binus University entitled “Pengaruh Suhu Terhadap Perubahan Gaya di Kabel Jembatan” or “Temperature Effect to Cable Force Variation of Bridge” with contract number: 12/AKM/PNT/2019 and contract date: 27 March 2019.

Authors: Hidayat I., Suangga M., Siagian G.
Title: Validation value of cable force using the accelerometer
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Siagian, G., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Cable is a tensile element on cable stayed bridges that works to support the load on the bridge deck due to the traffic load. In the design, it has been calculated the maximum load that can be received by each cable based on dead load, live load or environmental load. When the bridge operates, it is necessary to monitor the behavior of the bridge structure due to the work load based on the time function. It is very important for the bridge management to examine the cable forces that occur in real time, so that it can be immediately known if there is a cable force exceeding the maximum limit. One of the sensor tools that can be used to determine the frequency of the cable is accelerometer. The frequency data from accelerometer are calculated into the approach of formulas developed by Wei-Hua Hu, 2005. In this study, calculation cable forces consider the effect of sag cable or bending stiffness using Wei-Hua Hu formula. As a control data in cable force calculations, it used measurement data conducted by consultants. From the results for cable C7 located on left side of bridge needs to be re-tested. This happens because the value of the resulting cable force does not show similarity with the right-side (cable C7 located on right side). The cable C7 in left side of bridge has a frequency value of 1.24 and generate cable forces tends to decrease, where it should be increase for cables forces values. For other cable forces, the value of the cable force obtains a range difference between 0.28% - 9.23%. Longer cable such as cable M7, the cable force formula is less influenced by bending stiffness effects in calculation. In other words, the stiffness of the cable is small or does not affect the cable force. As for shorter cables in cables C2 and M2, the bending stiffness of the cables affects the calculation of the cable force. © 2018 Institute of Physics Publishing. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: accelerometer; bending stiffness; cable force; sag cable
Index Keywords: Accelerometers; Bridge cables; Cable stayed bridges; Stiffness; Bending stiffness; Bridge management; Bridge structures; Cable force calculations; Cable forces; Environmental loads; Sag cable; Tensile elements; Loads (forces)

Authors: Suangga M., Hidayat I., Juliastuti, Celine
Title: Temperature effect on cable tension forces of cable-stayed bridge
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Juliastuti, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Celine, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Cable is the most important element of cable-stayed bridge because it sustains most of the loads that work on the bridge deck and transfer the load to the pylon. The purpose of this research was to determine the effects of temperature on stayed cable of the bridge, to analyze the contribution of pylon and girder stiffness to the cable tension forces variation due to temperature effect. The result of the analysis using Finite Element Method then compared with the available field measurement data. To validate the finite element model, the dynamic finite element model of the bridge will be compared with the dynamic properties of the bridge from dynamic testing of actual bridge. It was found from the finite element model that he effects of temperature on the cable force is linear and the girder and pylon stiffness has significant contribution to the variation of cable tension force due to temperature change. The different between field measurement and finite element model has been found due to assumption on the temperature behavior of bridge deck, pylon and cable © 2018 Institute of Physics Publishing. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: cable; cable-stayed bridge; finite element method; temperature
Index Keywords: Bridge decks; Cables; Dynamic analysis; Finite element method; Stiffness; Temperature; Dynamic finite element model; Dynamic property; Effects of temperature; Field measurement; Field measurement data; Girder stiffness; Temperature behavior; Temperature changes; Cable stayed bridges

Authors: Hidayat I., Suangga M., Nataadmadja A.D., Yoshua
Title: The influence of crystalline to compressive strength of concrete in terms of mixing methods and mixer speed
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Nataadmadja, A.D., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Yoshua, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The problems will arrise for concrete stucture submerged under water. The performance concrete will decrease in that concrete such as less compressive strength and permeability. It is needed additive material has a water resistance in concrete mixture. In this research, it proposed crystalline as an additive material. The composition crystalline in concrete mixture is 0.8% from the weight of cement. The concrete mix design as follow SNI 03-2834-2000 standard. The method of concrete mixing used manual tool and concrete mixer. The mixer speed is set in this research are 25, 35, and 50 rotation perminutes (rpm). The delayed of addition crystalline in concrete mixture also done to know the effect of compressive strength concrete. The compressive strength is attained by using manual method and concrete mixer for 25 rpm, it is increased about 5.8% from the control concrete. However, the compressive strength is decreased for the speed of concrete mixer in 35 rpm and 50 rpm. The other additional material such as fly ash poured in concrete with crystalline 0.8%, but it doesn't improve the compressive strength of concrete. The delayed crystalline poured in fresh concrete doesn't affect the compressive strength of concrete. © 2018 Institute of Physics Publishing. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: compressive strength; concrete; crystalline material; rpm

Authors: Hidayat I., Suangga M., Maulana M.R.
Title: The effect of load position to the accuracy of deflection measured with LVDT sensor in I-girder bridge
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Maulana, M.R., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Serviceability of a bridge will decrease based on the function of time. Most likely due to the cyclic load from the traffic. The indicators which can be measured to determine the serviceability is the deflection of the girder. In this research, the PCI-Girder and vehicle load are analyzed by using the finite element method (Midas/Civil) Program. For comparison, the running vehicle test to the bridge has been conducted where the bridge deflections are measured using LVDT sensors on PCI-Girder Bridge. To find the effect of vehicle distance to the LVDV position, the running vehicle goes through on several lanes. The finite element program (Midas/Civil) gives relatively similar result to the measured deflection using LVDT sensors. However, when the vehicle load is situated far from the sensor, the result from both analysis showed significant differences. © 2017 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: Deflection; LVDT sensor; PCI-Girder; vehicle Load
Index Keywords: Deflection (structures); Vehicles; Bridge deflection; Finite element programs; Function of time; Girder bridges; Load positions; Lvdt sensors; Vehicle load; Vehicle tests; Finite element method

Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Juliastuti, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bontan, D.J., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: A cable is a flexible structural member that is effective at resisting tensile forces. Cables are used in a variety of structures that employ their unique characteristics to create efficient design tension members. The condition of the cable forces in the cable supported structure is an important indication of judging whether the structure is in good condition. Several methods have been developed to measure on site cable forces. Vibration technique using correlation between natural frequency and cable forces is a simple method to determine in situ cable forces, however the method need accurate information on the boundary condition, cable mass, and cable length. The natural frequency of the cable is determined using FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) Technique to the acceleration record of the cable. Based on the natural frequency obtained, the cable forces then can be determine by analytical or by finite element program. This research is focus on the vibration techniques to determine the cable forces, to understand the physical parameter effect of the cable and also modelling techniques to the natural frequency and cable forces. © 2017 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: cable forces; FFT Technique; natural frequency; vibration
Index Keywords: Fast Fourier transforms; Natural frequencies; Cable forces; Cable-supported structure; FFT (fast Fourier transform); FFT techniques; Finite element programs; Modelling techniques; vibration; Vibration techniques; Cables
References: Casas, J.R., A combined method for measuring cable forces: The cable-stayed Alamillo Bridge, Spain, Structural Enginering International (1994) Journal of the IABSE, 4, pp. 235-240. , November; Debora, S.N., Parivallal, S., Ravisankar, K., Hemalatha, G., Evaluation of Cable Tension Using Vibration Based Methodologies for Health Monitoring of Structures (2015) IJIRSET, 4; Chang, S.-P., Nonlinear Dynamic Analysis of Spatial Suspended Elasti Catenary Cable with Finite Element Method (2008) KSCE Journal of Civil Engineering, 12 (2), pp. 121-128; Alice, E., (2006), Measurement and Evaluation of Cable Forces in the Alvsborg Bridge (Stockholm: Royal Institute of Technology) Master Thesis; Erwin, K., (2006) Advanced Engineering Mathematic, , 9 (Hoboken: Wiley); Steiveman, D.B., (1953), (New York: Wiley amp; Sons Inc) A Practical Treatise on Suspension Bridges; Walther, R., (1988) Cable Stayed Bridges, , (London: L Thomas Telford Ltd) William Crozier, Penerjemah; Hiroki, Y., (1992), (Thailand: Asian Institute of Technology) Structural Dynamics; Rastandi Josia, I., (University of Indonesia) Presentation Material - Presentasi Jembatan Siak III by Dr. Ing

Title: Determine the coefficient of static wind on bridge structure
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan. 9, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan. 9, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Yanti, Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan. 9, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan. 9, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: A bridge structure should have a resistance to wind loads. The purpose of research is determine the coefficient of static wind load using computational calculations with FLUENT. The objects were modeled into a square 1x1 m, rectangle 2x1 m and circle diameter of 1 m with velocity of wind 10 m/s, 20 m/s and 30 m/s. The results described the value of the coefficient of drag force (CD) for square shape larger than rectangle. The coefficient of drag force (CD) for rectangular shape larger than circle. The value of coefficient of static wind do not depend on dimensional and wind speed. The coefficient value of wind static for Suramadu bridge which calculated by FLUENT Program and wind tunnel test have a similar chart patterns. © 2016 Penerbit UTM Press. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bridge structure; Coefficient of static wind
References: Senot, S., Pengukuran koefisien aerodinamis model-model jembatan bentang panjang (2005) Media Teknik Sipil, pp. 55-64. , http://eprints.uns.ac.id/993/2/3-12-1-PB.pdf, accessed 6 Februari 2015 from; Analisis karakteristik dinamik jembatan bentang panjang terhadap induksi getaran jembatan akibat beban angin (2014) Unisba. Authors: Hidayat I., Suangga M., Leonardo F., Juliastuti G.
Title: The comparison of slab deflection based on field measurement, manual calculation (Levy method) and finite element method (Program SAP 2000)
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Leonardo, F., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Juliastuti, G., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan, Kemanggisan, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Concrete slab is a structural system that uses beams as a support element slab. The placement of beams at the whole edges of slab, so that the load received by the slab can be transfer into beams. The slab will be deformed/deflection when the loads are given. The value of slab deflection is dependent on the placement of beam support at the edges. This research was conducted on the two boundary condition that is simple support at the two edges and rigid support at whole edges. Calculating the value of deflection based on the results of field measurements and then compared with Marcus Levy method and Finite element method (FEM). Based on the study, the numbers of mesh affected to the value of deflection. The results of deflection with Program SAP 2000 will be approached deflection by Method M. Levy for the mesh division with large numbers. The deflection of slab on the field measurement approached manual calculations and Program SAP2000 with a simple support at the surrounding the edges. The comparison of deflection was obtained for the simple support based on manual calculations and field measurement has a difference of 0.3% - 1%. Where the value of deflection on the field measurement is smaller than the manual calculation. © 2016 Penerbit UTM Press. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Deflection; FEM; Field measurement; Manual calculation
References: (1995) Building Code Requirements for Reinforced Concrete, , ACI Publication, American Concrete Institute (ACI), Detroit; (1963) Building Code Requirements for Reinforced Concrete, , ACI Committee 318, (ACI-318-63), Detroit: American Concrete Institute; Ugral, A.C., (1981) Stresses in Plates and Shells, , McGraw Hill, inc; Standar Nasional Indonesia, Tata Cara Perhitungan Struktur Beton Untuk Bangunan, , Gedung (SNI T-15-1991-03); (2000) Linear and Nonlinear Static and Dynamic Analysis and Design of Three-Dimensional Structures, , SAP, 2004, Computer and Structures, Inc. Title: The influence of fly ash in concrete compressive strength by using expanded polystyrene as a partial substitution of sand
Source title: International Journal of Applied Engineering Research
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Binus University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Binus University, Indonesia; Gunaedi, Civil Engineering Department, Binus University, Indonesia
Abstract: The concrete using expanded polystyrene materials (EPS) will decrease the density of the concrete, causing voids and decrease the concrete compressive strength. Material that can be used to fill voids in the concrete was fly ash. Fly ash used as a filler which was expected to increase the compressive strength. The objectives of this study were to determine the effect of fly ash on the concrete compressive strength by using expanded polystyrene (EPS) as a partial substitution of sand. The mix design method was based onSNI 03- 2834-2000, Provisions for Proportioning Normal Concrete Mixture. The percentage of EPS used as a partial substitution of sand was 0%, 10%, 20%, 30% from the weight of the fine aggregate. The percentage of fly ash used as filler was 0%, 7.5%, 10%, 12.5%, 15%, 17.5% from the weight of cement. The highest value of compressive strength for the concrete mix without EPS was concrete mixtures with proportions of 0% EPS + 15% fly ash which had the result of 25.86 MPa. For the concrete mixtures with EPS, the highest compressive strength was EPS 10 % + fly ash 15% with a value of 19.63 MPa. © Research India Publications.
References: Ahmad, M.H., Mix Design Of Styrofoam Concrete (2008) International Conference On Construction And Building Technology (ICCBT), A (26), pp. 285-296; Indonesia, B.S., (2000) SNI 03-2834-2000 : Tata Cara Pembuatan Rencana Campuran Beton Normal (Procedure for Normal Mixed Concrete), , Bandung; Indonesia, B.S., (2002) SNI 03-2847-2002 :Tata Cara Perhitungan Struktur Beton Untuk Bangunan Gedung (Procedure for Concrete Structure Calculation For Buildings), , Bandung; Indonesia, B.S., (2002) SNI 03-6815-2002 : Tata Cara Mengevaluasi Hasil Uji Kekuatan Beton (Procedures for Evaluating Compressive Strength of Concrete), , Bandung; Indonesia, B.S., (2002) SNI 06-6867-2002 : Spesifikasi Abu Terbang Dan Pozzolan Lainnya Untuk Digunakan Dengan Kapur (Specifications Fly Ash And Other Pozzolan For Use with Lime), , Bandung; Subhan, T.F.L., Compressive And Tensile Strength Of Expanded Polystyrene Beads Concrete (2005) Sipil, Mesin, Arsitektur, Electro (SMARTek), pp. 227-235; Susanto, R., (2011) Analisis Penambahan Fly Ash Dalam Campuran Beton Dengan Expanded Polystyrene Sebagai Agregat Ringan (Analysis of Fly Ash With Mixed Concrete In Expanded Polystyrene as Lightweight Aggregate), , Jakarta : Universitas Bina Nusantara; Yusuf, R., (2011) Pengaruh Penggantian Pasir Dengan Expanded Polystyrene Terhadap Kuat Tekan Dan Berat Jenis Beton (Effect of Expanded Polystyrene as a Substitution of Sand Against Compressive Strength And Density of Concrete), , Jakarta : Universitas Bina Nusantara

Title: The value compressive strength and split tensile strength on concrete mixture with expanded polystyrene coated by surfactant span 80 as a partial substitution of fine aggregate
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, I., Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Siauwantara, A., Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The value of the density normal concrete which ranges between 2200-2400 kg/m3. Therefore the use of Expanded Polystyrene (EPS) as a subitute to fine aggregate can reduce the density of concrete. The purpose this research is to reduce the density of normal concrete but increase compressive strength of EPS concrete, with use surfactant as coating for the EPS. Variables of substitution percentage of EPS and EPS coated by surfactant are 5%,10%,15%,20%,25%. Method of concrete mix design based on SNI 03-2834-2000 "Tata Cara Pembuatan Rencana Campuran Beton Normal (Provisions for Proportioning Normal Concrete Mixture)". The result of testing, every increase percentage of EPS substitution will decrease the compressive strength around 1,74 MPa and decrease density 34,03 kg/m3. Using Surfactant as coating of EPS, compressive strength increase from the EPS's compressive strength. Average of increasing compressive strength 0,19 MPa and increase the density 20,03 kg/m3,average decrease of the tensile split strength EPS coated surfaktan is 0,84 MPa. © Owned by the authors, published by EDP Sciences, 2014.

Authors: Hidayat I., Suangga M., Setiadi M.M.
Title: Comparison of design standards for prestressed highway bridges
Source title: International Journal of Applied Engineering Research
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Setiadi, M.M., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: Prestressed concrete is a system of specialized concrete structures by providing certain initial stress on the element structure before it is used to support the external load. In this research, type I-Girder WIKA standard for bridges were considered with longitudinal spansof 35 m, transverse spans of 12.4 m, girder heightof2100 mm. The purpose of this study to calculate the deflection and stress at the girder with different standard for Highway Bridge.Three standards considered for this comparison including of Bina Marga, AASHTO, and British Standard.Based on the analysis, it was found that the value of the stress in the Ultimate Limit Stress (ULS) and Service Limit State (SLS)and the value of deflection are still below the allowable values. This indicates that the type I-Girder considered is meet all the criteria implied by the three design standards. The important aspect when designing a prestressed concrete bridge is a combination of loading, the resistance factor, the design criteria, and the limit valueof deflection. The different parameter between the design ctandardis the value of the resistance factor. Bina Marga and AASHTO standards use the resistance factor values of 0.75 and 0.9, while for a British Standard resistant factor is not adopted but the value of material factor (γm) is used with the value of 1.15. The value for short-term lossdue to concrete shortening of Bina Margais equal to zero. This is due to the tendon are tensionedsimultaneously. According to British Standard, long-term losses due to creep and shrinkage are calculated together, however for Bina Marga and the AASHTO LRFD calculations, separate analysis are required. © Research India Publications.
References: (2012) AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design specifications; (2011) Perencanaan Struktur Beton Pratekan Untuk Jembatan, , 021/BM/2011; Hussein, A., Strength Design Requirements of ACI-318M-02 Code, BS 8110, and EuroCode2 for Structural Concrete: A Comparative Study (2006) Journal of Engineering and Development, 10 (1); Lin, T.Y., (1963) Design of Prestressed Concrete Structure, , (2nd edition).New York:Wiley International Edition; Sankar, Midhun, B., Jacob, Priya, A., Comparison of Design Standarts for Steel Railways Bridges (2013) Journal of Engineering Research and Aplications(IJERA), pp. 1131-1138

Authors: Suangga M., Hidayat I., Stephanie J.
Title: Comparison of the calculated stress value on a “I-girder” bridge to the field sensor measurement results
Source title: International Journal of Applied Engineering Research
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Departement, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suangga, M., Civil Engineering Departement, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Civil Engineering Departement, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Stephanie, J., Civil Engineering Departement, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: The calculation of stress/tension bridge is performed to determine the ability of a bridge that was built due to its external loads and self weight. The purpose of this research was to perform a comparative analysis of the stress value due to the live load calculation program based on the results of Midas/Civil with the field measurement results and stress sensors determine the effect of the modulus of elasticity of concrete parameters on the stress value of pre-stressed bridge. The method used in this research is the analytical calculations based on actual conditions measured in the field. Loading test method is based on the actual condition of the integrated load testing methods. The results obtained in this research is when the load works right on top of the bridge girder then the stress value will be close to the actual stress value. In the effect analysis of the modulus of elasticity of concrete shows that the modulus does not affect the stress value. Moreover, on the diaphragm modeling workload which is right on top of the girder has less stress value. Therefore, it can be concluded that the program modeling results approaches with the actual conditions in the field, where the field measurements results are relatively the same compared to the results of the calculation program. © Research India Publications.
Author Keywords: Bridge stress value; MIDAS civil; Modulus of Elasticity; Prestressed bridge
References: (2008) ST350 Strain Transducer Instruction Manual, , Canada: Camphbell Scientific, Inc; Chen, W.F., Duan, L., (2000) Bridge Engineering Handbook, , London: Boca Raton; Perencanaan Struktur Beton Untuk Jembatan (Concrete Design for Bridge Structure), , Department of Public Works; Standar Pembebanan Untuk Jembatan (Standard of Loading for Bridge Structure), , Department of Public Works; Perencanaan Struktur Beton Pratekan Untuk Jembatan (Design Presstressed Concrete for Bridge Structure), , Bina Marga, Department of Public Works

Authors: Suangga M., Hidayat I., Lutter B.
Title: Condition assessment of PCI bridge girder a result of the reduction prestressing force
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suangga, M., Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Lutter, B., Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: PCI bridge girders is known and widely used for many construction e.g.: bridge, wharf, flyover, and other application. PC Bridge girders have two types: Pre - tensioned girders and post - tensioned girders. In pre tensioned girders, prestressing in carried out first then after that the fresh concrete poured. The prestressing process in only carried off after the concrete has sufficient strength. In this study, analysis was conducted for PCI bridge girder with span is 40 meters. Based on the data geometry bridge dimension girder, material girder, and material strands cable, it will be analyzed to calculate the natural frequencies and moment capacity using finite element program (Midas/Civil program). So it can be estimated how much the percentage reduction prestress force on the bridge until PCI bridge structure collapses. From the calculation, it found that the pattern comparison between reduction prestressing force and natural frequency are linear. These results are also similar for natural frequency versus moment capacity.PCI bridge will collapse when the reduction prestreesing force of 45 % to 50 % from the total loss of prestressing. © Owned by the authors, published by EDP Sciences, 2014.

Title: Experimental study on epoxy polystyrene as a partial substitution of fine aggregate of concrete mixture
Affiliations: Pembangunan Jaya University, Blvd Bintaro, Bintaro Jaya, 7th Sector Tangerang Selatan, Banten, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Setiawan, A., Pembangunan Jaya University, Blvd Bintaro, Bintaro Jaya, 7th Sector Tangerang Selatan, Banten, Indonesia; Hidayat, I., Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This study has an objective partial substitution of sand in concrete materials. On the use of 5% EPS concrete compressive strength characteristics obtained amounted to 18.69 MPa (down approximately 20.9% of the normal mixture). While the use of 10% EPS, decrease concrete compressive strength of 21.67% ie 18.51 MPa. Modulus of elasticity of concrete decrease with the addition of the percentage of EPS, the use of EPS up to 40% decrease modulus of elasticity to be 16.219 MPa (down around 21%). The relationship between the modulus of elasticity (E), Specific Gravity (wc), compressive strength (f/c) and the percentage of EPS (p) can be expressed in an empirical equation as follows: E = (wc)1,5·0,05·exp(-0,23·p)·√f/c..
Author Keywords: Compressive strength; Concrete; Epoxy polystyrene; Flexural strength; Modulus of elasticity; Tensile splitting strength
